thread.title: Texas prediction: What it will take for Longhorns to power past Kansas State
thread.title_full: Texas prediction: What it will take for Longhorns to power past Kansas State | Dallas Morning News

author: Nick Castillo
title: Texas prediction: What it will take for Longhorns to power past Kansas State
text:
Kansas State at Texas
When: 11 a.m. Saturday
Where: Darrell K Royal - Texas Memorial Stadium in Austin
Records: Kansas State (3-3, 0-3 Big 12); Texas (2-4, 1-2)
Last Meeting: Kansas State 23, Texas 0 on Oct. 25, 2014
TV: Fox Sports 1
What's on the line?
The Longhorns have an opportunity to keep their momentum rolling after beating Oklahoma 24-17 on Oct. 10. A win would put Texas in a better position make a bowl game. The Longhorns will have to prove that Kansas State doesn't have their number as the Wildcats have won six of the last seven games in the series.
Kansas State is looking for its first win in Big 12 play. The Wildcats have lost two closes games in conference play against Oklahoma State and TCU. But Kansas State suffered its worst loss Saturday against the Sooners, 55-0. Saturday's game against Texas will be a chance for the Wildcats to bounce back from their blowout loss.
When Kansas State has the ball
When the Wildcats have the ball they'll look to maintain possession. Kansas State has averaged 32 minutes of possession this season.
The Wildcats will try to run the ball with freshman running back Justin Silmon and junior quarterback Joe Huebner. Silmon has rushed for 285 yards and two touchdowns, and Huebner has run for 321 yards and six touchdowns.
The Longhorns will have to guard Kansas State's run-pass option which the Wildcats have found success running.
Kansas State is also an efficient redzone offense. The Wildcats have been able to score points when they get into the redzone 90 percent of the time. Texas will have to prevent Kansas State from finding its way into the redzone.
When Texas has the ball
When the Longhorns get the ball, they'll look to run the ball.
Texas has had some success on the ground this season and will look to continue to build off the 313 yard rushing performance it had against Oklahoma.
The Longhorns will utilize redshirt freshman Jerrod Heard's athleticism. They use him multiple ways to get him in the open field from quarterback draws to zone-read plays. Texas will also try to get the ball into the hands of its running backs - sophomore D'Onta Foreman and senior Johnathan Gray.
Texas has struggled to get its passing game going but will try to get Heard going against Kansas State.
The Longhorns will also look to use junior quarterback Tyrone Swoopes in a short-yardage run package.
Prediction
The weather forecast for Saturday's game shows a high percentage of rain which means whichever team is able to establish its running game will likely be the winner.
Texas has shown its capable being a run-heavy team but the Wildcats have a tenacious rushing defense which could stymie the Longhorns' run game. While Kansas State has been able to run the ball, it isn't a top rushing offense. At times Texas has given up big yards to opponents' ground games. The Longhorn defense will need to a performance much like its game against Oklahoma.
Although the Wildcats have beaten Texas six of the last seven times, the Longhorns find a way to pull out a win Saturday.
Score: Texas 24, Kansas State 14
